data.title: Mountains visibility
data.solution:
import sys
import math

# Auto-generated code below aims at helping you parse
# the standard input according to the problem statement.

n = int(input())
altitude = int(input())
angle = []
for ind,i in enumerate(range(n)):
    distance, height = [int(j) for j in input().split()]
    angle.append((ind+1,(height-altitude)/distance,distance))

angle.sort(key=lambda p:p[2])

liste = ["1"]
angle_cur =angle[0][1]
for ind,i in enumerate(angle[1:]):
    if i[1]>angle_cur:
        liste.append(str(ind+2))
        angle_cur = i[1]
# Write an answer using print
# To debug: print("Debug messages...", file=sys.stderr, flush=True)

print(" ".join(liste))
data.statement:
Given an observer on top of a mountain, list all the other visible moutains from him, if they are not hidden by the other ones.
For simplicity, assume a 2D-world (X and Z axes) where all the mountains are aligned in the same line of sight from the observer. They are only described by their distance and height and are provided in ascending order of distance.
A high mountain can be hidden by a smaller mountain, if the small mountain is much closer to the observer than the farther mountain.

testCases.title: First hiding the others, with height

data.constraints:
2 ≤ [[N]] ≤ 10
0 ≤ [[ALTITUDE]] , [[DISTANCE]] , [[HEIGHT]] ≤ 10000
All peaks at different vertical angles from the observer, in order to prevent from peak alignment.
Mountains are ordered by ascending distance.
data.stubGenerator:
read N:int
read altitude:int
loop N read distance:int height:int
write answer
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> The number of mountains [[N]].
<<Line 2 :>> An integer representing the [[ALTITUDE]] of the observer.
<<[[N]] following lines :>> Two integers [[DISTANCE]] and [[HEIGHT]] for each mountain (ordered by ascending distance)

[[DISTANCE]] represents the distance from the observer to the mountain top (seen from above, as for a 2D map, not the direct distance in 3D).
[[HEIGHT]] : Mountain height
[[DISTANCE]], [[HEIGHT]] and [[ALTITUDE]] are in the same units.
data.outputDescription:
Provide the list of visible mountains, in ascending distance  order from the observer.
Mountains indexes start from 1.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Given an observer on top of a mountain, list all the other visible moutains from him, if they are not hidden by the other ones.
For simplicity, assume a 2D-world (X and Z axes) where all the mountains are aligned in the same line of sight from the observer. They are only described by their distance and height and are provided in ascending order of distance.
A high mountain can be hidden by a smaller mountain, if the small mountain is much closer to the observer than the farther mountain.
Input
Line 1: The number of mountains N.
Line 2 : An integer representing the ALTITUDE of the observer.
N following lines : Two integers DISTANCE and HEIGHT for each mountain (ordered by ascending distance)

DISTANCE represents the distance from the observer to the mountain top (seen from above, as for a 2D map, not the direct distance in 3D).
HEIGHT : Mountain height
DISTANCE, HEIGHT and ALTITUDE are in the same units.
Output
Provide the list of visible mountains, in ascending distance order from the observer.
Mountains indexes start from 1.
Constraints
2 ≤ N ≤ 10
0 ≤ ALTITUDE , DISTANCE , HEIGHT ≤ 10000
All peaks at different vertical angles from the observer, in order to prevent from peak alignment.
Mountains are ordered by ascending distance.
Example
Input
2
0
1000 500
2000 1500
Output
1 2
